NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTERS
DuPont Circle Office Building
1346 Connecticut Avenue, N. W.
Washington 6, D. C.
OFFICE OF THE VICE PRESIDENT
May 16, 1961
Dr. Samuel L. Becker, Director
Division of Television, Radio, Film
State University of Iowa
Iowa City, Iowa
Dear Sam:
This summer the NAEB will conduct a seminar at Madison, "Wisconsin, which has
been rather aptly described by someone as “Allerton - 12 Years Later”.
This seminar, which will bring together the NAEB Board of Directors and certain
committee chairmen and members, will be devoted to a searching self-analysis.
In general, those attending will examine carefully the role now being played by
the NAEB in light of what it should be doing, what it is best equipped to do, what
the future should hold, etc. This will be examined in the context of the entire
educational broadcasting movement and the NAEB’s place therein.
The above is a very sketchy resume of what the planning committee has in mind,
and more detailed information will be sent to you within two or three weeks.
However, it is important at this time to find out whether or not you will be able
to attend.
The seminar will be held July 16 - 19. Participants will arrive Sunday afternoon,
the 16th. Morning and afternoon sessions will be held on Monday, Tuesday,
and Wednesday and the seminar will close about 5:00 p.m. on Wednesday the
19th As has been the case with past seminars, it is anticipated that most parti¬
cipants will want to stay over on Wednesday night and depart on Thursday morning.
There will be no formal evening sessions, thus giving participants time for in¬
formal sessions and discussions.
The NAEB will pay your living expenses (room and board) while you are at the
seminar and rooms will be provided in University of Wisconsin housing, with
meals being eaten in the dining room. In addition, the NAEB will reimburse you
